Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Noise in Gene Expression: How are They Controlled?

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this CAREER project is to understand how noise in gene expression is controlled. Gene expression, similar to many other biochemical reactions involving small copy number components, is inherently stochastic. Such stochasticity inevitably leads to considerable noise in gene expression. However, "noisy gene expression" is intuitively at odds with the incredible precision cells and organisms achieve during development and growth. How do cells cope with noise, adopting a robust growth pattern while the underlying molecular events are inherently stochastic? In this work, real-time gene expression dynamics in single E. coli cells with unprecedented single molecule sensitivity is followed and the full noise spectrum of gene expression, both the amplitude and frequency, is quantitatively analyzed. Knowledge obtained from this study may bring in the possibilities of designing and building synthetic networks with desired properties to carry out specific functions. The educational component of this project focuses at two levels: K-12 and college. An annual Fun with Science Summer Camp that is freely open to local low-income, underserved students in eight adjacent city elementary schools will be organized to provoke their interest in learning science. At the college level, an elective course Single Molecule Methods will be developed and offered to graduate students in the School of Medicine. The integrated research and education plans allow the PI to expand the participation of underrepresented minority students in scientific research, provide broad training opportunities for high school, undergraduate and graduate students and advance the understanding of the noise control mechanisms in gene expression.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the time supported by the NSF CAREER award, we published three research articles (Feng, Hensel et al. 2012; Hensel, Feng et al. 2012; Hensel, Weng et al. 2013), one invited review (Hensel and Xiao 2013), one perspective (Hensel and Xiao 2009), and one video protocol (Hensel, Fang et al. 2013). We currently have one invited review submitted (Weng and Xiao 2014), and two research manuscripts in preparation (Fang, Hensel et al. 2014; Weng, Lagda et al. 2014). Below I summarize the main intellectual merit and broader impact of our work.

 Intellectual Merit

 

The main goal of the project is to understand how fluctuations in gene expression are minimized to ensure precise gene regulation. To achieve this goal, the first step we took was to develop a single-molecule gene expression reporter to follow the expression dynamics of transcription factors (TFs, (Hensel, Feng et al. 2012). TFs are proteins that bind to DNA and determine when, where and at what levels a target gene is expressed. Many TFs are expressed at low levels and are intrinsically prone to large fluctuations, or noise in gene expression due to the small copy number of mRNA and protein involved. Hence, it is intriguing to ask how a TF minimizes fluctuations in its own expression so that these fluctuations do not affect its regulation of downstream genes. In the gene regulatory network of E. coli, a model organism of bacterial cells, more than half of TFs auto-regulate their own expressions. One intuitive hypothesis is that these autoregulations may function to suppress noise in TFs' own expression. To test this hypothesis, we followed the expression dynamics of a TF, the bacteriophage λ repressor CI, under different autoregulatory contexts in live E. coli cells. We found in contrary to the common belief, intrinsic fluctuations in cI expression was largely determined by CI expression level irrespective of autoregulation. Instead, extrinsic, cell-to-cell variation was primarily responsible for CI concentration fluctuations, and negative autoregulation minimized CI concentration heterogeneity by counteracting extrinsic noise and minimizing the persistence of noise. We also developed an analytical framework for isolating different components of noise in gene expression to aid the quantitative modeling of gene regulation (Feng, Hensel et al. 2012).

Next, we developed a high-resolution, single-molecule imaging method in live E. coli cells to investigate the role of TF-mediated DNA looping  in gene regulation (Hensel, Weng et al. 2013). TFs can often bind distant DNA sites to form a DNA loop. In vivo gene reporter assays have shown that changes in distal TF binding site affect gene expression, and in vitro biochemical assays have visualized the formation of DNA using purified DNA and protein components. However, formation of DNA loops in live cells have not been directly visualized and its influence on gene regulation not quantified. We were able to label two DNA loci only 2.3 kilobases apart and track their separations with ~40 nm accuracy in live E. coli cells.
